channel.description: Recent content in Deep Learning on

item.title: Diffusion Models Part 7 - Conditioning and Text-to-Image
item.description: Unconditional diffusion generates random images. Conditioning lets you control what’s generated.

item.title: Diffusion Models Part 6 - Sampling and Generation
item.description: Model trained. Now generate images. Start with random noise, repeatedly denoise, arrive at a realistic image.

item.title: Diffusion Models Part 5 - Training the Denoiser
item.description: Architecture ready. Now train it. Diffusion training is simple in principle but requires careful implementation for good results.

item.title: Diffusion Models Part 4 - U-Net Architecture
item.description: The denoiser needs to see both big picture and fine details.

item.title: Diffusion Models Part 3 - The Noise Process
item.description: Diffusion’s key insight: destroying structure is easy (add noise), creating structure is hard.

item.title: Diffusion Models Part 2 - Neural Networks Basics
item.description: Neural networks learn to denoise images. Before building a full diffusion model, understand the building blocks: conv layers, activations, residual connections.

item.title: Diffusion Models Part 1 - Understanding Tensors
item.description: Before diving into diffusion models, master the foundation: tensors. Every image is a tensor.

item.title: Fine-Tuning LLMs - Customizing Language Models
item.description: Pretrained LLMs are generalists. Fine-tuning makes them specialists. Adapt to your domain, your style, your task.

item.title: Variational Autoencoders - Probabilistic Generative Models
item.description: Autoencoders compress data to a bottleneck, then reconstruct. VAEs make the bottleneck probabilistic - encode to a distribution, sample from it, decode.

item.title: BERT - Bidirectional Language Understanding
item.description: Before BERT: train models from scratch for each task. After BERT: pretrain once, fine-tune everywhere.

item.title: Transformer Architecture - The Model Behind Modern AI
item.description: The paper that changed everything: “Attention Is All You Need” (2017).

item.title: Positional Encoding - Giving Transformers a Sense of Order
item.description: Self-attention is permutation equivariant. Shuffle the input tokens, output shuffles the same way.

item.title: Self-Attention - The Key Mechanism in Transformers
item.description: Regular attention: query from one sequence, attend to another. Self-attention: query, key, value all come from same sequence.

item.title: Attention Mechanisms - Part 1: The Core Idea
item.description: LSTMs helped with long-range dependencies. Attention does something more powerful - direct connections from anywhere to anywhere.

item.title: LSTM - Learning Long-Term Dependencies
item.description: RNNs have short memory. Information from early timesteps fades quickly. LSTMs fix this with gates that control information flow.

item.title: Layer Normalization - Keeping Activations Stable
item.description: Deep networks have unstable activations. Values explode or vanish as they pass through layers.

item.title: Conv + ReLU - The Building Block of CNNs
item.description: Convolution followed by ReLU. This pattern repeats hundreds of times in modern image networks.

item.title: 2D Convolutions - How Neural Networks See Images
item.description: Images are grids of pixels. Fully connected layers would need billions of parameters.

item.title: Cross-Entropy Loss - The Classification Loss Function
item.description: Why do we use cross-entropy for classification? What does it actually measure?

item.title: Embeddings - Representing Stuff as Vectors
item.description: Embeddings are everywhere now. Words, sentences, images, users, products… anything can be an embedding.

item.title: Tokenization - How Text Becomes Numbers
item.description: ML models don’t read text. They need numbers. Tokenization bridges that gap.

item.title: Matrix Multiplication - The Operation Behind Everything
item.description: Neural networks are mostly matrix multiplication. Understanding this operation deeply helps understand everything else.

item.title: Softmax - Turning Numbers into Probabilities
item.description: Neural network outputs raw numbers (logits). For classification, you want probabilities.

item.title: Leaky ReLU - Fixing Dead Neurons
item.description: ReLU is great but has a problem. Neurons can die. Leaky ReLU fixes this with one small change.

item.title: ReLU - Why Neural Networks Learned to Use Simple Functions
item.description: Sigmoid was the standard. Then ReLU came along and made deep learning actually work.

item.title: Gradient Descent - How Neural Networks Learn
item.description: Neural networks learn by adjusting weights to reduce error. Gradient descent tells you which direction to adjust.
